Furthermore, all conditioned dharmas are also called causal conditions.

As for the sequential condition, excluding the past and present final mind and mental factors of an arhat, all other past and present mind and mental factors can give rise to a sequence, which is called the sequential condition.
As for the condition as object and the dominant condition, they are all dharmas.
Moreover, if a bodhisattva wishes to know the specific and common characteristics of the four conditions, he should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

Why is this so?ğŸ”½If the effect exists prior to the cause, this is not so;
if the effect does not exist prior to the cause, this is also not so.
If it existed prior [to the cause], then there would be no cause;
if it did not exist prior [to the cause], what would serve as the cause?
If it existed prior [to the cause] but then existed, it would also be possible for it to arise without a cause.
Moreover, because we see the effect arising from the cause, we call it a cause;
if the effect did not exist prior [to the cause], how can it be called a cause?
Moreover, if the effect arises from the cause, then the effect belongs to the cause, and the cause is not independent, but rather depends on another cause;
if the cause is not independent, how can it be said that the effect arises solely from this cause?
In this way, one knows that there is no condition.
Moreover, past mind and mental factors are completely extinguished and cannot function. How can they be the immediately preceding condition?

The present mind has no sequence. If it is the immediately preceding condition for the future mind that is about to arise, the future does not yet exist. How can it be the immediately preceding condition?
In this way, there is no immediately preceding condition.
In this way, all dharmas are without characteristics and without conditions. How can it be said that there is an object condition?
If all dharmas belong to nothing, rely on nothing, and are all equal, how can it be said that there is a dominant condition?

Answer:

You do not understand the characteristics of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, and for this reason it is said that the four conditions are all unobtainable within prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ. PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ does not abandon or destroy any dharmas, it is ultimately pure and free from all conceptual proliferation.
As the Buddha has said there are four conditions, but it is those with little wisdom who become attached to the four conditions and give rise to false theories;
In order to destroy attachment, it is said that all dharmas are truly empty and there is nothing to be destroyed.
Just as mental phenomena arise from the combination of internal and external sense bases and conditions, this mind is like an illusion, like a dream, deceptive, and without any fixed nature;
The mental factors are also like this.
This mind is born together with mental factors such as feeling, perception, and volition.
These mental factors have the same characteristics and the same objects, and are therefore called associated.
The mind takes the association with mental factors as its cause, and the mental factors take the association with the mind as their cause. This is called the associated cause.
The corresponding cause is like close friends and acquaintances, combining to form events.
The co-arising cause is that all conditioned dharmas each have a co-arising cause, because they arise together they mutually assist each other;
it is like brothers, because they are born together they mutually support each other.
The homogeneous cause is that the good seeds of the past are the cause of the present and future good dharmas;
the good seeds of the past and present are the cause of the future good dharmas.
The same is true for the unwholesome and indeterminate.
Thus, all dharmas each have their own homogeneous cause.
The universal cause is that the fetters eliminated by the truth of suffering and the truth of the origin are the cause of all defiled dharmas, this is called the universal cause.
The retributive cause is that due to the causes and conditions of karmic actions, one obtains good and evil retributions, this is the retributive cause.
These five causes are called causes and conditions.
The mind and mental factors arise in sequence and are uninterrupted, this is called sequential condition.
The mind and mental factors arise due to the objects, this is called the condition as object.
When dharmas arise, they do not obstruct each other, this is called non-obstruction.
Furthermore, the mind and mental factors arise from four conditions;
The attainment of non-perception and the attainment of cessation arise from three conditions, excluding the condition as object;
The other formations not associated with the mind and form arise from two conditions, excluding the condition as antecedent and the condition as object.
Because the nature of conditioned dharmas is weak, there is none that arises from one condition.
The mind and mental factors born of retribution arise from five causes;
Because the non-obscuring indeterminate is not a defiled dharma, the universal cause is excluded.
The defilements also arise from five causes, excluding the cause of retribution.
Why is it so?
Because the defilements are obscured and retribution is non-obscured, the cause of retribution is excluded.
The form born of retribution and the formations not associated with the mind arise from four causes;
Because form is not the mind or mental factors, the associated cause is excluded;
Because non-obscuring indeterminate dharmas exclude the pervasive cause.
Defiled form and mental factors not associated with mind also arise from four causes;
Because they are not mind or mental factors, they exclude the associated cause;
Because they are defiled, they exclude the retributive cause.
All other mind and mental factors, except for the first pure mind, all arise from four causes, excluding the retributive cause and the pervasive cause.
Why is this?
Because they are not indeterminate, they exclude the retributive cause; because they are not defiled, they exclude the pervasive cause.

The remaining dharmas not associated with mind, namely form and mental factors not associated with mind, if they have their own seed cause, then they arise from three causes, excluding the associated cause, the retributive cause, and the pervasive cause;
If they do not have their own seed cause, then they arise from two causes:
the co-arising cause and the unobstructed cause.
The first pure mind and mental factors arise from three causes:
the associated cause, the co-arising cause, and the unobstructed cause.
In the first undefiled mind, form and the various activities not associated with mind arise from two causes:
co-arising cause and unobstructed cause.
There is no dharma that arises from a single cause.
If it arises from the six causes, it is called the four conditions.
The bodhisattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, observes the four conditions in this way, and the mind is unattached;
although distinguishing these dharmas, one knows they are empty, all like magical illusions;
although there are various distinctions within the magical illusions, the wise one observes them and knows they are unreal, merely deceiving the eyes.
In order to distinguish and know the dharmas of ordinary beings, they are all inverted, false, and unreal, therefore there are the four conditions, how can they be real?
The dharmas of the sages arise from the dharmas of ordinary beings, therefore they are also unreal, as explained earlier in the eighteen emptinesses.
The bodhisattva, within prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, cannot grasp any dharma with a fixed nature, therefore it cannot be destroyed;
Because sentient beings are attached to the empty dharmas of causes and conditions, they are called breakable.
It is like a small child who sees the moon in the water, gives rise to an attachment in the mind, wants to grasp it but cannot obtain it, and feels sorrowful in the mind!
A wise person teaches, saying:
Although it can be seen with the eyes, it cannot be grasped with the hands;
But break what can be grasped, not what can be seen!
Bodhisattvas observe and understand that all dharmas arise from the four conditions, but do not grasp the definite characteristics within the four conditions.

The combination of the four conditions gives rise to [things] like the moon in the water. Although they are false and nonexistent, they must arise from the causes and conditions of the moon in the water, not from other conditions.
All dharmas are also like this. Each arises from its own causes and conditions, and also has no definite reality.
For this reason it is said:
If bodhisattvas wish to understand the characteristics of causes, sequential conditions, conditional conditions, and dominant conditions as they truly are, they should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

The meaning of the four conditions in Abhidharma is like obtaining the truth at the beginning, but as you seek deeper and deeper, you fall into wrong views, as explained above in your refutation of the four conditions.
Furthermore, the causes of all dharmas are based on the four conditions. What do the four conditions depend on?
If there are causes, there is an infinite regress. If there is an infinite regress, there is no beginning. If there is no beginning, there are no causes.
If that is so, all dharmas should have no causes!
If there is a beginning, the beginning has no cause.
If there is something without a cause, it does not depend on causes and conditions.
If that is so, all dharmas also do not depend on causes and conditions to exist!
Furthermore, there are two kinds of dharmas that arise from causes and conditions:
If it already exists in the conditions, then it does not depend on conditions to arise, and it is not a condition;
If it does not exist in the conditions, then there are no individual conditions.
Because of the four conditions of conceptual proliferation, there are such faults as these.
As in the perfection of wisdom, emptiness cannot be attained, and there are no such faults.
As in the world, people's ears and eyes see birth, old age, sickness, and death, this is existence;
If one finely seeks its characteristics, it cannot be attained.
For this reason, in the perfection of wisdom, only wrong views are eliminated, and the four conditions are not refuted.
Therefore, it is said:
If one wishes to know the characteristics of the four conditions, one should study the perfection of wisdom.

[Treatise] The suchness of all dharmas has two aspects:
First, the individual characteristics; second, the true characteristics.
As for the individual characteristics, earth is characterized by solidity;
water is characterized by wetness;
fire is characterized by heat;
wind is characterized by motion. In this way, the various dharmas are distinguished and each has its own characteristics.
As for the true characteristics, within the individual characteristics, seeking the true [nature] cannot be found, it cannot be destroyed, and it is free from all faults.
As explained in the emptiness of individual characteristics:
If earth is truly characterized by solidity, why is it that when glue, wax, etc. come into contact with fire, they lose their inherent nature?
A person with spiritual powers can enter the earth as if it were water;
Moreover, when wood and stones are dispersed, they lose their solid characteristics.
Moreover, when earth is broken down into subtle particles, and those particles are further broken down, they ultimately return to emptiness, also losing their solid characteristics.
Thus, when investigating the characteristics of earth, they cannot be found;
If they cannot be found, they are actually all empty, and emptiness is the true characteristic of earth.
All distinct characteristics are also like this, and this is called thusness.
As for the nature of dharmas, as explained above, the emptiness of each dharma has distinctions, which is thusness;
Being the same in being empty is the nature of dharmas.
This nature of dharmas also has two aspects:
First, using a mind free from attachment to distinguish the natures of various dharmas, each having its own nature;
Second, it is called the immeasurable dharma, namely the true characteristic of all dharmas.
As the Sutra of Upholding the Mind says:
The nature of dharmas is immeasurable. Although Å›rÄvakas attain the nature of dharmas, because their wisdom is limited, they cannot explain it as immeasurable.

Question:
Are suchness, dharma nature, and ultimate reality, these three things the same?
Or are they different?
If they are the same, why speak of three?
If they are three, they should now be distinguished and explained!
Answer:
These three are all different names for the true characteristics of all dharmas.
Why is this?
Ordinary beings lack wisdom and engage in false views regarding all dharmas, such as permanence, bliss, purity, reality, self, and so forth.
When the Buddha's disciples contemplate according to the original characteristics of dharmas, at that time they do not see permanence, which is called impermanence;
they do not see bliss, which is called suffering;
they do not see purity, which is called impurity;
they do not see reality, which is called emptiness;
they do not see self, which is called non-self.
If one does not see permanence but sees impermanence, that is a false view;
Seeing suffering, emptiness, non-self, and impurity is also like this, and this is called suchness.
Suchness is as it originally is, and cannot be destroyed.

For this reason, the Buddha taught the three dharmas as the Dharma seals, namely the seal of impermanence of all conditioned dharmas, the seal of non-self of all dharmas, and the seal of quiescent extinction of nirvana.

It is like a small child who sees the moon in the water, enters the water to search for it, and becomes sad when unable to find it.

Furthermore, the suchness of all dharmas is such that when dharmas have not yet arisen, at the time of arising they are also like this; having arisen, in the past and present they are also like this.

Question:
If an unarisen dharma is called non-existent,
an arisen dharma in the present has a dharma that can be used;
Because there are characteristics of activity and function based on the present dharma, one recalls past events, which is called the past.
The three times are each different, and should not be truly the same. How can it be said that the equality of the three times is called suchness?
Answer:
Within the true characteristics of all dharmas, the three times are equal and one without difference.
As it is said in the Suchness Chapter of the Prajnaparamita Sutra:
The suchness of the past, the suchness of the future, the suchness of the present, and the suchness of the Tathagata are one suchness without difference.
Furthermore, the arising of dharmas has already been refuted in a previous discussion;
If there is no arising of dharmas, then future and present [dharmas] also have no arising. Why are they not equal?
Moreover, the past has no beginning, the future has no end, and the present has no abiding;
Therefore, the equality of the three times is called thusness.
Having practiced thusness, one enters into the immeasurable Dharma-nature.
Dharma-nature means that dharmas are nirvÄá¹‡a, indestructible, and beyond conceptual proliferation.

Those with sharp faculties immediately understand that all these dharmas are the Dharma-nature;

It is like a great smith who beats on a stone and then obtains gold.
Furthermore, just as the nature of water flows downward and eventually converges into the ocean, merging into a single flavor;
All dharmas are also like this. All general and specific characteristics return to the nature of dharmas, becoming the same single characteristic. This is called the nature of dharmas.

All dharmas are also like this. Wisdom discriminates and seeks, reaching the suchness, from suchness entering its own nature, as originally born, extinguishing all conceptual proliferation. This is called the nature of dharmas.

All dharmas are also like this. Various distinctions, acceptance and rejection are not the same. Reaching one's own nature and then stopping, there is no further place to go beyond. This is called the nature of dharmas.
Actual reality is as explained above:
The nature of dharmas is called actual, and the place of entry is called reality.
Furthermore, each dharma has nine aspects:
First, having a substance;
Second, each having its own characteristics;
For example, although the eyes and ears are both created from the four elements, the eyes alone can see, while the ears have no function of seeing;
Also, like fire, which has heat as its characteristic, it cannot moisten;
Third, all dharmas each have their own power;
For example, fire has the power to burn, while water has the power to moisten;
Fourth, all dharmas each have their own causes;
Fifth, all dharmas each have their own conditions;
Sixth, all dharmas each have their own effects;
Seventh, all dharmas each have their own nature;
Eighth, all dharmas each have their own limitations;
Ninth, all dharmas each have their own methods of opening up and penetrating.
When dharmas arise, there are nine things in total, including their substance and other dharmas.
Knowing that each of these dharmas has its own essence and is complete, this is called the lower suchness of the world.
Knowing that these nine dharmas will eventually return to change, end, and extinction, this is called the middle suchness.
It is like this body, which is born from impurity and, although bathed and adorned, will eventually return to impurity.
This dharma is neither existent nor nonexistent, neither born nor extinguished. It extinguishes all contemplated dharmas and is ultimately pure. This is called the higher suchness.
Furthermore, some say:
The dharma within these nine matters is called suchness.

It is like the dharma of earth being solid and heavy, the dharma of water being cold and wet, the dharma of fire being hot and illuminating, the dharma of wind being light and moving, and the dharma of mind being cognition.
Such dharmas are called suchness.
As it is said in the sutra:

Whether there are Buddhas or not, suchness, the characteristics of dharmas, and the state of dharmas always abide in the world. It is said that ignorance conditions the various activities, always being the same as the original dharma.
DharmatÄ refers to the nature among the nine dharmas.
Reality refers to the attainment of the fruit among the nine dharmas.
Furthermore, the true nature of all dharmas abides eternally and is unmoving.
Because of ignorance and other afflictions, sentient beings deviate and become crooked within the true nature.

The buddhas and sages use various skillful means to teach the Dharma, destroy ignorance and other afflictions, and enable sentient beings to regain the true nature as it originally was, without deviation. This is called suchness.
The true nature, when combined with ignorance, becomes transformed and is then impure;

Reality refers to entering into the dharmatÄ and knowing that the dharmatÄ is immeasurable and boundless, the most subtle, and there are no dharmas that surpass the dharmatÄ or transcend the dharmatÄ. The mind then becomes content and no longer seeks elsewhere, and thus one attains realization.
It is like traveling, setting out day after day without stopping, and when reaching the destination, no longer having the intention to go further;
The practitioner abiding in the ultimate reality is also like this.

It is like arhats and pratyekabuddhas abiding in the ultimate reality, even if countless buddhas expound the Dharma for them, they are unable to make further progress and do not take rebirth in the three realms again.

If a bodhisattva enters this dharma-nature, even though they know the ultimate reality, if they have not yet perfected the six perfections and transformed sentient beings, at that time if they realized [nirvana], it would hinder the attainment of buddhahood.
At that time, the bodhisattva, by the power of great compassion and diligence, cultivates all practices again.

Furthermore, knowing that within the true characteristics of dharmas there is no permanent dharma, no blissful dharma, no self-nature dharma, and no real dharma, they also abandon this contemplation of dharmas;

if the fire is extinguished and the heat is exhausted, it returns to coldness as before.
Using various contemplated dharmas is like water obtaining fire;

Suchness always abides in reality.
Why is it so?

The marvelous culmination of this is called the true limit.

It is like taking the earth and all the mountains of the trichiliocosm and grinding them into dust motes;

In this way, the Buddha and the great bodhisattvas can know the number of dust particles in worlds equal to the sands of the Ganges River, let alone in one world.
Furthermore, immeasurable is spoken according to the human mind.

Question:

Moreover, some people consider the earth to be solid, but the mind is formless and all this is false.
Therefore, the Buddha said:
The power of the mind is great.
Because of practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, the great earth is pulverized into dust motes.

Water has less smell, so its movement is superior to earth;ğŸ”½Fire has less smell and taste, so its power is superior to water;

The mind is powerful because it is free from four things.
Moreover, because the mind is bound by many afflictions and fetters, it causes the power of the mind to be weak.
Although the contaminated wholesome mind is free from afflictions,
because the mind grasps the characteristics of dharmas, its power is also small.
Although the uncontaminated mind of the two vehicles does not grasp characteristics, its wisdom is limited;
and when it emerges from the uncontaminated path, it discriminates and grasps the characteristics of dharmas according to worldly conventions, thus not exhausting the power of the mind.
The wisdom of the Buddhas and great bodhisattvas is immeasurable and boundless, and they always abide in meditation, without discriminating between the world and nirvÄá¹‡a.
The true characteristics of dharmas are actually no different, but there are differences in the superiority of their wisdom;

One who practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is ultimately pure, unobstructed, and in a single thought can count the subtle dust motes of the great earth and mountains in the trichiliocosm of the ten directions, which are as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, let alone the worlds in the ten directions, each of which is as numerous as the sands of a single Ganges River!
Furthermore, if one departs from prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, even if one attains spiritual powers, one will not be able to know as above.
For this reason, it is said:
If one wishes to attain such great spiritual power, one should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Some people say:
Among all things, water is the greatest.
Why is it so?
The great earth, above and below, in the four directions, is not without water.
If the Lord of the Protectors of the World does not regulate the rain of the heavenly dragons, and there is no water-absorbing pearl, then heaven and earth will be flooded.
Moreover, because of the condition of water, all sentient and non-sentient beings in the world can grow and flourish. For this reason, we know that water is the greatest.

Some people say:

Why is it so?
Because it eliminates smell and taste.
Moreover, although the sources of water are numerous, fire can extinguish it.

For this reason, we know that fire is the greatest.
Therefore, the Buddha said:
If a bodhisattva wishes to blow out a great fire, he should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Question:

Answer:

Question:

The bodhisattva practicing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, by means of dhyÄna concentration, attains spiritual powers and can transform the body to be large, and the wind from the mouth is also large, thus able to extinguish it.

For this reason, the celestials and humans in the world, seeing this spiritual power, all submit in reverence.

Moreover, it is extremely difficult to establish the trichiliocosm, but because of the bodhisattva's merit and wisdom, he has the power to control it.
Furthermore, some say:
Among the four elements, the power of wind is the greatest, because it lacks form, smell, and taste, and its movement is the greatest.
Why is it so?
Just as space is boundless, so too is the wind;
All things that grow and decay are due to the wind;
The force of the great wind can destroy the mountains of the trichiliocosm.
For this reason, the Buddha says:
One who can block the force of the wind with a single finger should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Why is this so?
The true nature of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is immeasurable and boundless, enabling the power of the finger to be like this.
[Sutra] Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who wish to sit in full lotus posture and fill the space in the trichiliocosm should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ!
[Treatise] Asks:

Answers:
Because BrahmÄ-king rules the trichiliocosm and gives rise to a mind of wrong views, considering himself great;
Seeing the bodhisattvas sitting in full lotus posture filling the entire sky, their arrogant minds were pacified.
Moreover, within the power of spiritual penetrations, through skillful means, one can become many, and many can become one;

It is also in order to manifest rare and difficult events that they sit filling the entire sky.
It is also in order to prevent ghosts, spirits, and dragon kings from harassing sentient beings, that they sit filling the entire sky, bringing peace and security to sentient beings.

Sutra: Furthermore, if Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas wish to use a single hair to lift all the Mount Sumerus in the trichiliocosm and throw them beyond other worlds, innumerable asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of Buddha-lands away, without disturbing any sentient beings, they should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ!
Treatise: Question:

Answer:
It is not necessarily that there is lifting, this clarifies that the Bodhisattva's power can lift them.
Furthermore, the Bodhisattvas, in order for the Buddha to expound the Dharma, first adorn the trichiliocosm, removing the mountains and leveling the ground.
As the Lotus Sutra says:
The Buddha, wishing to gather the transformed Buddhas, first levels the ground.
He also wishes to manifest rare events, causing sentient beings to see them.
Why is this so?
One Mount Sumeru is 84,000 yojanas high. If it is difficult to lift up this one mountain, how much more so for the billion Mount Sumerus in the trichiliocosm!

If it is difficult to lift up the billion Mount Sumerus in the trichiliocosm with a single hair, how much more so to throw the billion Mount Sumerus beyond innumerable asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of worlds with the tip of a single hair!
When sentient beings see the rare events of the bodhisattva, they all give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment and think like this:
This bodhisattva has not yet attained Buddhahood, and his spiritual powers are already like this, let alone when he attains Buddhahood!
For this reason, it is explained like this.
Sutra: If you wish to use a single meal to make offerings to the Buddhas and Sangha in the ten directions, each as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, you should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ!

If one wishes to make offerings to the buddhas and the saá¹…gha with a single piece of clothing, flowers, incense, garlands, powdered incense, ointments, burnt incense, lamps, banners, canopies, and so forth, one should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
[Treatise] Question:

If a bodhisattva were to make offerings of a single meal to a single buddha and the saá¹…gha, that would still be a difficult task, let alone to the buddhas and the saá¹…gha in the ten directions, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River.
Answer:
The merit of making offerings lies in the mind, not in the act.
If a bodhisattva with a great mind were to make offerings to all the buddhas and the saá¹…gha in the ten directions with a single meal, he would not be hindered by distance;
therefore, all the buddhas would see and accept it.
Question:
Since the buddhas possess omniscience, they all see and accept it;

Answer:
Although the saá¹…gha does not see or know it, the giver still obtains merit by making offerings to them.
It is like a person who sends a messenger to make offerings to another person. Although that person does not receive it, this person has already obtained the merit of giving.

Furthermore, the bodhisattvas have accomplished immeasurable and inexhaustible merits. With a single meal, they can make offerings to the buddhas and the sangha in the ten directions, satisfying them all without depletion;
It is like a spring that flows without drying up.
It is like Manjushri who, with a single bowl of joy pills, made offerings to 84,000 monks, satisfying them all without depletion.

Furthermore, the bodhisattvas here make offerings to the buddhas in the ten directions with a single bowl of food, and the food and drink in front of the buddhas in the ten directions are fully provided.

Furthermore, when a bodhisattva practices prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, he attains immeasurable dhyÄna concentrations and immeasurable wisdom and skillful means, and therefore there is nothing he cannot do.
Because prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is unobstructed, the mind of this bodhisattva is also unobstructed in what it does.

This bodhisattva can make offerings to the buddhas and their assemblies in the ten directions, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, not to mention those as numerous as the sands of one Ganges River.
Clothing, flowers, incense, necklaces, powdered incense, ointments, burnt incense, lamps, banners, canopies, and so forth are also like this.
[Sutra] Furthermore, Shariputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who wish to cause sentient beings in worlds as numerous as the sands of the Ganges in each of the ten directions to all be endowed with morality, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation, to attain the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, the fruit of arhatship, and even to attain nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ!
[Treatise] The meaning of the five aggregates has been explained above.
The fruit of stream-entry is of two kinds:

By severing the eighty-eight bonds, one attains the unconditioned fruit of stream-entry.
Second, those who are practitioners of faith and practitioners of the Dharma, abiding in the knowledge of the path, who attain the realization of the fruit of stream-entry.

Xi ji means one, and jia mi means coming.

Because arhats have exhausted all afflictions, they should receive offerings from all devas, nÄgas, and spirits.

Sutra: Furthermore, Shariputra!
When a bodhisattva-mahasattva practices prajna-paramita and gives a gift, he should make distinctions like this:

The Treatise says: Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know the true characteristics of all dharmas, without grasping or rejecting, without destroying anything. Practicing the unobtainable prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, with a mind of great compassion they cultivate meritorious practices;

Although the objects given are the same, the amount of merit is determined by the superiority or inferiority of the mind.

ÅšÄriputra said:

Although one obtains much merit in a good field, it is still not as good as the mind.

Like the arhat Kará¹‡e, who once offered a flower to a Buddha stÅ«pa. For ninety-one kalpas, he enjoyed happiness among humans and gods. By the power of his remaining blessings and virtues, he attained arhatship.

The mind, the object, and the field of merit, the three matters are all wonderful;
As explained in the first chapter of the Prajnaparamita Sutra:
The Buddha scatters beautiful flowers to the Buddhas of the ten directions.

Furthermore, giving for the sake of nirvana also obtains great rewards;
Giving with a mind of great compassion in order to save all sentient beings also obtains great rewards.

Being born in a kshatriya family up to attaining Buddhahood.

How does giving lead to being born in a kshatriya family up to attaining Buddhahood?
Answer:
If someone, due to giving and upholding precepts, attains wealth and nobility among humans and gods,
If someone, due to giving and upholding precepts with utmost sincerity, is born in a ká¹£atriya family,
A ká¹£atriya is a king or a great minister.
If one is attached to the wisdom of the scriptures but does not harm sentient beings, and gives and upholds precepts, one is born in a brÄhmaá¹‡a family.

A householder is a petty person with great wealth.

If one's giving and upholding precepts are slightly pure, one is disgusted with family affairs, delights in listening to the Dharma, and makes offerings to good people, one is born in the abode of the Four Heavenly Kings.
Why is it so?
Because in that place, whatever one needs or desires arises in the mind and is obtained;
One always sees the sages and good people here, and the mind arises to make offerings, because one is close to the place of cultivating blessings.

If one's giving and upholding precepts are pure, one makes offerings to one's parents and those they respect, and one's mind desires to attain the supreme, one will be reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
If one's giving and upholding precepts are pure, and one delights in learning, with a gentle mind, one will be reborn in the Heaven of YÄma.

If one's giving and upholding precepts are pure, and one makes these two things even more excellent, delights in hearing much, distinguishes between good and bad, delights in nirvÄá¹‡a, and one's mind is attached to merit, one will be reborn in the Tuá¹£ita Heaven.
If one gives, deeply upholds the precepts, hears much, delights in learning, and lives by one's own abilities, one will be reborn in the NirmÄá¹‡arati Heaven.

When giving, if one upholds the precepts even more purely, delights in hearing much, and is very self-important, unable to endure hardship oneself, and seeks pleasure from others, one will be reborn in the ParanirmitavaÅ›avartin Heaven.
What others think of, diligently and attentively, they transform into the five desires of female form, and one takes them away and has mastery over them.
It is like a commoner who suffers and works for himself, but a powerful person takes it away.
Furthermore, when practicing generosity, one is reborn in the heavens due to the causes and conditions of one's vows.
As the sutra says:
There are people who practice generosity and uphold precepts a little, but do not know about meditation. When they hear about the Four Heavenly Kings, they always aspire for it in their minds.
The Buddha said:
'When the life of such a person ends, it is certain that they will be reborn in the heavens of the Four Heavenly Kings;
It is the same up to the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others.'
Furthermore, when someone practices generosity and upholds precepts, when practicing generosity, their mind experiences joy. If they give much, the joy is also much;
Thinking like this, they abandon the five desires, remove the five hindrances, and enter the first dhyÄna, up to the heaven of neither perception nor non-perception.
The definitions of the four dhyÄnas and four formless concentrations are as explained above.
Furthermore, someone practices generosity to the Buddha and the Buddha's disciples, and hears the correct Dharma from them;
Because of this giving, the person's mind becomes pliant, wisdom bright and sharp, they give rise to the eightfold noble path, sever the three bonds, and attain the fruit of stream-entry;
Up to the Buddha way, it is also like this. Because of this giving and hearing their teaching, they give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Furthermore, giving without being free from desire gives rise to wealth and nobility among humans and in the six desire heavens;
If giving with a free mind, one is born in the Brahma world heavens up to the heaven of vast fruit;
If giving with a free mind from form, one is born among the formless heavens;

Giving free from the three realms for the sake of nirvana attains the way of the Å›rÄvakas;ğŸ”½When giving, if one dislikes evil and busyness, delights in quietude, and delights in profound wisdom, one attains the pratyekabuddha;
When giving, if one gives rise to a mind of great compassion, wishes to deliver all, and seeks the foremost, profound, and ultimate pure wisdom, one attains the way of the Buddha.
Sutra: Furthermore, Shariputra!

When a bodhisattva-mahasattva practices prajna-paramita and gives, by the power of wisdom and skillful means, he is able to perfect the paramitas of giving, morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom.
Shariputra said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
How does a bodhisattva-mahasattva, when giving, by the power of wisdom and skillful means, perfect the paramitas of giving up to wisdom?
The Buddha told Shariputra:
Because the giver, receiver, and wealth cannot be obtained, one is able to perfect the paramita of giving;
Because sin and non-sin cannot be obtained, one perfects the paramita of morality;
Because the mind is unmoved, one perfects the paramita of patience;
Because of physical and mental diligence without slacking off, they are replete with the perfection of vigor;
Because of non-dissipation and non-savoring, they are replete with the perfection of meditation;
Because of knowing that all dharmas are unobtainable, they are replete with the perfection of wisdom.
The meaning of replete has already been extensively explained.
Wisdom and skillful means are explained here, namely, the unobtainability of the three things.
Question:
As for wisdom and skillful means, they can accomplish their tasks without destruction, and there is nothing else to do;
Now, if these three things are destroyed, one should fall into annihilation. How can it be said to be wisdom and skillful means?
Answer:
There are two kinds of unobtainability:
1. The unobtainability of attainment, 2. The unobtainability of non-attainment.
The unobtainability of attainment falls into annihilation;
If the unobtainability of non-attainment is wisdom and skillful means, it does not fall into annihilation.
If one gives without wisdom and skillful means, one grasps at the characteristics of the three things;
If one uses the emptiness of the three things, then one grasps at the signless.

One who has wisdom and skillful means has from the beginning not seen the characteristics of the three things. For this reason, one who has wisdom and skillful means does not fall into existence or non-existence.
Furthermore, destroying the afflictions while giving is called wisdom and skillful means.
Furthermore, giving with a mind of great compassion towards all sentient beings is called wisdom and skillful means.
Furthermore, giving the merit of the blessings cultivated in immeasurable past and future lives, dedicating it towards supreme perfect enlightenment, is also called wisdom and skillful means.

Furthermore, recollecting and rejoicing in the merit of all Buddhas and their disciples in the ten directions and three times, giving and dedicating it towards supreme perfect enlightenment, is called wisdom and skillful means.
Such various kinds of power are the meaning of wisdom and skillful means.
Up to the wisdom and skillful means of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ are also like this.
[Sutra] Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas wish to attain the merits of the buddhas of the past, future, and present, they should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ!
[Treatise] Question:
The merits of past buddhas have already ceased, the merits of future buddhas have not yet come to be, and the merits of present buddhas cannot be attained;

Moreover, the merits of buddhas in the three times are all unobtainable, so how can it be said that if one wishes to attain the merits of the buddhas of the three times, one should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?
Answer:
It does not say if one wishes to attain the merits of the buddhas of the three times;
One wishes to attain the merits of the buddhas of the three times oneself, without any deficiency.
Why is this?
The merits of all buddhas are equal, with neither more nor less.
Question:

If that is so, why is it said that AmitÄbha Buddha's lifespan is immeasurable, his radiance extends for thousands of myriads of yojanas, and he has been liberating sentient beings for immeasurable eons?
Answer:
The worlds of the buddhas are of various kinds, some are pure, some are impure, and some are mixed.
As the Sutra on the Thirty-three Heavens says:
The Buddha was dwelling in the Heaven of the Thirty-three during the summer retreat.
When the time for the confession ceremony arrived, the four assemblies had not seen the Buddha for a long time and were sorrowful and unhappy.
They sent MaudgalyÄyana to tell the Buddha:
'World-Honored One!
How can you abandon these sentient beings and dwell in that heavenly realm?'
At that time, the Buddha told MaudgalyÄyana:
'You observe the trichiliocosm!'

MaudgalyÄyana, by the Buddha's power, observed and saw that in some places the buddhas were expounding the Dharma to the assembly, in some places they were sitting in meditation, and in some places they were begging for food. In this way, he saw various activities of the Buddha's work.
MaudgalyÄyana immediately prostrated with his five limbs to the ground. At that time, Mount Sumeru shook greatly, and the devas were all greatly frightened.
MaudgalyÄyana wept and bowed to the Buddha, saying:
The Buddha has great compassion, not abandoning any, and thus transforms and delivers beings in various ways!
The Buddha told MaudgalyÄyana:

Beyond what you have seen, in the east there is a country whose ground is made entirely of gold. The Buddha's disciples there are all arhats with the six supernatural powers and unobstructed [abilities].
Furthermore, beyond that, in the east there is a country whose ground is made entirely of white silver. The Buddha's disciples there are all studying the path of pratyekabuddhas.
Furthermore, beyond that, in the east there is a country whose ground is made entirely of the seven treasures. That ground always has immeasurable light;
the Buddha's transformed disciples there are all bodhisattvas who have attained dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s and various samÄdhi gates, and abide in the stage of nonretrogression.
MaudgalyÄyana!
You should know that all those Buddhas are my body.
In this way, in the worlds of the east, equal to the sands of the Ganges River, whether they are adorned or not, they are all my body performing Buddha-works.
As it is in the east, so it is in the south, west, north, the four intermediate directions, and above and below.
